sen.j: サザエの壺焼き（サザエのつぼやき）は、巻貝のサザエ（栄螺）の料理法の一種。
sen.e: Sazae no Tsuboyaki' (A turbo cooked in its own shell) is a way to cook a snail, sazae (turbo.)
Sazae no Tsuboyaki' (A turbo cooked in its own shell) is a way to cook a snail, sazae (turbo.)
Sazae no Tsuboyaki (Turbo cooked in its own shell) is a way of cooking a snail, sazae (turbo).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 壺焼きは、壺状の調理器の中で蒸し焼きにするもののほか、巻貝の貝殻をそのまま調理器として使う料理法をも意味するが、後者の料理法の代表的な事例。
sen.e: Tsuboyaki' (literally, cook in a vase) means two things: one is to smother food in a vase-shaped cooker, and another is to use a snail shell itself as a cooker and process the snail, and 'sazae no tsuboyaki' is a typical example of the latter.

sen.j: おそらく当初は漁師の浜料理であったと思われ、その起源は不明である。
sen.e: Perhaps, it might have been fishermen's way of cooking on a fishing boat or at beachside at first, however, the origin of it is not known.
While it is believed to have been a beachside recipe derived by fishermen, it's exact origin is unknown.

sen.j: 最初は、サザエをそのまま焚き火などに投入し、海水で塩味をつけるという程度の、シンプルで野趣あふれる料理だったものと思われる。
sen.e: It is thought that this might have been a simple and wild way to cook by only putting a turbo in fire and flavored it salty with seawater.
It is thought that this might have been a simple and exciting way to cook by placing it in a bonfire and flavoring it with salty seawater.

sen.j: 壺焼きであったかどうかは不明だが、1588年に豊臣秀吉が後陽成天皇を聚楽第に招いた際の献立の中に「焼栄螺」の文字を見ることができるという。
sen.e: Although it is not known whether it was a 'tsuboyaki', it is said that there appeared characters "焼栄螺" (burnt turbo) on the menu card of the banquet at the time when Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI invited Emperor Goyozei to his Jurakudai residence in 1588.

sen.j: 現在のかたちに似たサザエの壺焼きは、江戸時代には登場していた。
sen.e: It is known that 'sazae no tsuboyaki' similar to today's form appeared by the Edo period.

sen.j: たとえば十返舎一九の『東海道中膝栗毛』（1802年〜1822年にかけて出版）には、由比町（静岡県）のあたりで「売るはさざえの壺焼きや」という言及がある。
sen.e: For example, there was an expression that "What we are selling in here is Sazae no Tsuboyaki" at around Yui-cho (Shizuoka Prefecture) in Ikku JUPPENSHA's book "Tokai dochu hizakurige" (Shanks' Pony along the Tokaido Road) (Published from 1802 to 1822.)

sen.j: また、江戸時代後期の随筆『寐ものがたり』には、九紋龍という力士の逸話として「栄螺の壺焼を十六七も喰ひ」という表現がある。
sen.e: There was another episode of a sumo wrestler Kumonryu that "He ate 16 or 17 of sazae no tsuboyaki" in an essay titled "Nemonogatari" (Tales of Sleeping) at the later Edo period.

sen.j: このことから、遅くとも江戸時代中期には、浜料理から脱して商品としての「サザエの壺焼き」が売り出されていたことがわかる。
sen.e: These facts shows that 'sazae no tsuboyaki' turned from a easy seaside cooking to a merchandise to sell at shops by the middle of Edo period at the latest.

sen.j: 明治時代にはいってからは、たとえば報道画家・山本松谷（1869年?-1965年）の『風俗画報』のうち『銀座地蔵前縁日』（1901年頃か?）にサザエの壺焼きを商う屋台が描かれており、サザエの壺焼きが海辺の町から都市部に進出してきていたことがわかる。
sen.e: In Meiji era, a news reporter-painter, Shokoku YAMAMOTO (1869? ~ 1965) reported with picture titled "Ginza Jizo-mae ennichi" (a fair in front of the Ginza-Jizo, guardian deity of children) in "Fuzoku Gaho" (Manners and Customs in Pictures) magazine (around 1901?) that there were street stalls selling 'sazae no tsuboyaki,' and this shows that the shops moved into urban areas from seaside towns.

sen.j: サザエの壺焼きは、広く分布する料理であるため、作り方は、地域や時代によって多くのヴァリエーションがある。
sen.e: As 'sazae no tsuboyaki' is widely seen everywhere in the country, the recipe varies depends on time and regions.
